sections.title: Overview
lines: This document describes the client experience for the AWS Encryption
The top level client supports configuration settings that need to be
coordinated between encrypt and decrypt.  Coordinating static
settings between encrypt and decrypt across hosts is complicated.  It
is important that all messages that could be sent to a host can be
decrypted by that host.  A top level client makes such settings hard
a client encrypts can be decrypted by the same client.

sections.title: Encrypted Message Format
lines: The message format is a binary format, but it is a common mistake for
users to attempt decryption on the Base64 encoding of this data
instead.  Because the first two bytes of the message format have a
very limited set of possible values (currently they are in fact
fixed), the first two bytes of the Base64 encoding of a valid message
To make diagnosing this mistake easier, implementations SHOULD detect
the first two bytes of the Base64 encoding of any supported message
(../data-format/message-header.md#type) and fail with a more specific
.  In particular, the hex values to detect for the
current set of versions and types are:
| Version and type (hex) | Base64 encoding         | Base64         |
Note that the bytes that follow the initial two in the Base64
encoding partially depend on subsequent bytes in the binary message
format and hence are not as predictable.

sections.title: Consumable Bytes
lines: In the scope of an operation, bytes are considered consumable if:
*  The operation has not yet processed those bytes.
*  The operation has access to those bytes.
*  Those bytes are intended to be processed.  This intention is
expressed through the specific streaming interface.
For example, in a framework where a customer is sending input bytes
to an operation and that operation must write the output bytes to
some sink, the input bytes received from the customer are considered
consumable.  Here the customer is expressing intent to process their
For a framework where a customer is requesting output bytes from an

produce bytes, this is slightly more complicated.  Bytes are
*  Those bytes have not yet been processed.

sections.title: Release
lines: An operation releases bytes when the operation intends those bytes to
For example, in a framework where a customer is sending input bytes
to an operation and that operation must write the output bytes to
some sink, bytes are considered released once the operation writes
For a framework where a customer is requesting output bytes from an
operation and that operation must read from some source in order to
produce bytes, bytes are considered released once those bytes are
available to be read by the customer.
If bytes are processed by an operation, that does not imply that the
operation is allowed to release any result of that processing.
decrypt and encrypt operations specify when output bytes MUST NOT be
released and when they SHOULD be released

sections.title: Inputs
lines: In order to support streaming, the operation MUST accept some input
*  There MUST be a mechanism for input bytes to become consumable
*  There MUST be a mechanism to indicate that there are no more input
These mechanisms are used to allow the operation to process input
The bytes that represent the entire input to the operation are the
bytes that the customer intended to be processed.

sections.title: Outputs
lines: In order to support streaming, the operation MUST produce some output
*  There MUST be a mechanism for output bytes to be released
*  There MUST be a mechanism to indicate that the entire output has
These mechanisms are used to allow the operation to produce output
The bytes that represent the entire output to the operation are the
bytes that were released up until an end was indicated.
Operations MUST NOT indicate completion or success until an end to

lines: By using the mechanisms for Section 2.4 and Section 2.5, some actor
expresses intent through a streaming interface for bytes to be made
consumable to the operation and for bytes to be released by the
The behavior of the operation specifies how the operation processes
consumable bytes, and specifies when processed bytes MUST NOT and

sections.title: HKDF Encryption Key
lines: If an algorithm suite uses HKDF to derive the encryption key the AWS
Encryption SDK MUST use HKDF with the following specifics
*  The hash function MUST be specified by the algorithm suite key
-  The input keying material MUST be the data key generated by the
-  The length of the input keying material MUST equal the key
derivation input length (Section 2.10.8) specified by the
algorithm suite encryption key derivation settings
-  If there is no salt length defined for the algorithm suite
encryption key derivation commitment setting (Section 2.6), the
the salt MUST be a byte sequence of 0 as long as the hash
-  If salt length is defined for the algorithm suite encryption
key derivation commitment setting (Section 2.6), the salt MUST
with a length equal to the salt length
-  The input pseudorandom key MUST be the output from the extract
-  The length of the output keying material MUST equal the
encryption key length (Section 2.10.4) specified by the
-  If key commitment (Section 2.10.9) for the algorithm suite
encryption key derivation setting (Section 2.6) is True, then
the input info MUST be a concatenation of the algorithm suite
ID (Section 2.10.1) followed by the string "DERIVEKEY" as UTF8
-  If key commitment (Section 2.10.9) for the algorithm suite
encryption key derivation setting (Section 2.6) is False, the
the input info MUST be a concatenation of the algorithm suite
ID (Section 2.10.1) followed by the message ID (../data-format/

sections.title: HKDF Commit Key
lines: If an algorithm suite uses HKDF to derive the commitment key the AWS
Encryption SDK MUST use HKDF with the following specifics
*  The hash function MUST be specified by the algorithm suite
-  The input keying material MUST be the data key generated by the
-  The length of the input keying material MUST equal the key
derivation input length (Section 2.10.8) specified by the
algorithm suite commit key derivation setting
-  The salt MUST be the message ID (../data-format/message-
header.md#message-id) with a length of 256 bits
-  The input pseudorandom key MUST be the output from the extract
-  The length of the output keying material MUST equal the
algorithm suite data length (Section 2.10.16) specified by the
-  The input info MUST the string "COMMITKEY" as UTF8 encoded
bytes by the algorithm suite commitment settings
For algorithm suites that support commitment, the AWS Encryption SDK
SHOULD only perform the extract step once and use the same output
from the extract step for both the encryption key and the commitment
Verification of the commitment key MUST be a constant time

sections.title: ECDSA
lines: Specification: ANS X9.62-2005 (Not available publicly, but the
specification for ECDSA is replicated in SEC 1 version 2.0
copies of ANS X9.62 is available at http://www.x9.org.)
The Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) is a signature
If specified to use ECDSA, the AWS Encryption SDK MUST use ECDSA with
*  The elliptic curve is specified by the algorithm suite.  The
specific curves are defined in Digital Signature Standard (DSS)
*  The hash function is specified by the algorithm suite.
*  When included in the message (../data-format/message.md), the
output signature value is encoded using the ANS.1 structure
"ECDSA-Sig-Value" defined in section C.5 of Sec 1 version 2.0
*  If serialized, the binary form of the verification key is equal to
the elliptic curve point Q compressed according to section 2.3.3

sections.title: Overview
lines: Duplicate multi-region key ids create ambiguity about which Region to
contact.  This is better resolved outside of the AWS Encryption SDK.
While preferring the "local" Region is a seductive solution, this can
not be 100% correct.  First, because not all code runs in an AWS
Region, and second because customers may want create privacy controls
around their data.  In this case nearby region may exists and store
ciphertext, but may be restricted from having the AWS KMS keys.  In
any complicated deployment determining the closest, or preferred
region is itself a complicated task.  It will be easier for customers
to reason about this criteria and ensure their code is correct if the
AWS Encryption SDK offers one and only one configuration for a
behavior. e.g.  If the preferred region logic results in an ambiguous
configuration is informed and they can resolve the ambiguity.  Rather
than attempting to resolve it ourselves.
Preferring the local region does not suffice: not all code runs in an
AWS Region boundary, and customers need to assert intentions to use a

SHA-512 hash of the concatenation of the following byte strings, in

sections.title: Decryption Materials
lines: When the caching CMM receives a Decrypt Materials request, it MUST
calculate the cache entry identifier as the SHA-512 hash of the
concatenation of the following byte strings, in the order listed
1.  The SHA-512 hash of a UTF-8 encoding of the caching CMM's
2.  The two-byte algorithm suite ID corresponding to the algorithm
3.  The concatenation of the lexicographically-sorted SHA-512 hashes
of the serialized encrypted data keys, where serialization is as
defined in the Encrypted Data Key Entries specification
4.  A sentinel field of 512 zero bits (or equivalently, 64 null
bytes), indicating the end of the key hashes
5.  The SHA-512 hash of the serialized encryption context

keyrings will be capable of obtaining the plaintext data key from the

Multi-keyrings will produce a set of encrypted data keys
interface.md#onencrypt) that includes the encrypted data keys of

(Section 2.6.1) or a member of child keyrings (Section 2.6.2)) that

As such, any keyring (keyring-interface.md) that is capable of

The
decrypt and encrypt operations specify when output bytes MUST NOT be
released and when they SHOULD be released.
*  There MUST be a mechanism for input bytes to become consumable.

bytes.

In order to support streaming, the operation MUST accept some input
within a streaming framework.
*  There MUST be a mechanism for output bytes to be released.

*  There MUST be a mechanism to indicate that the entire output has
been released.

In order to support streaming, the operation MUST produce some output
within a streaming framework.

Operations MUST NOT indicate completion or success until an end to
the output has been indicated.

The behavior of the operation specifies how the operation processes
consumable bytes, and specifies when processed bytes MUST NOT and
SHOULD be released.

After a cache entry's TTL has elapsed, we say that the entry is _TTL-
expired_, and the local CMC MUST NOT return the entry to any caller.

Each cache entry has a time-to-live (TTL) field that represents a
point in time at which the cache entry MUST be considered invalid.

The local CMC MUST NOT store more entries than this
value, except temporarily while performing a Put Cache Entry
operation.

The local CMC MUST accept entry capacity values between
zero and an implementation-defined maximum, inclusive.

The _entry pruning tail size_ is the number of least recently used
entries that the local CMC MUST check during Section 2.7 for TTL-
expired entries to evict.

When calling the Put Cache Entry operation, the caller MUST provide a
time delta value, which the local CMC uses to derive the cache
entry's time-to-live (TTL) value.

When performing a Put Cache Entry operation, the local CMC MUST prune

The local CMC SHOULD also periodically evict all TTL-expired entries
among the "N" least recently used entries.

To prune TTL-expired cache entries, the local CMC MUST evict all TTL-
expired entries among the "N" least recently used entries, where "N"
is the Entry Pruning Tail Size (Section 2.5.2).

The plaintext data key SHOULD offer an interface to zero the
plaintext data key.

The verification key MUST fit the specification for the signature
algorithm (algorithm-suites.md#signature-algorithm) included in this
decryption material's algorithm suite (Section 2.3.4.2.1).

This structure MAY include
any of the following fields:

These
structures define a group of related fields that MUST hold certain
properties.

Wherever these structures are referenced in this
specification, implementations MUST ensure that all properties of a
structure's fields are upheld.

While these structures will usually be represented as
objects, lower level languages MAY represent these fields in a less
strictly defined way as long as all field properties are still
upheld.
